Ever had a lost in translation moment? Here's a travel tale that takes the scenic route! Meet Michael Lewis, 22, who turned a 400-mile flight into a 12,000-mile adventure. Michael, intending to fly from Los Angeles to Oakland. He had just arrived from London aboard an Air New Zealand flight and just followed the crowd, many of whom were traveling on to Auckland. He was asked where he was going, he said ‚ÄòOakland,‚Äô and received a boarding pass and got back on the same aircraft. It wasn't until they mentioned Tahiti mid-flight that he realized the mix-up. Imagine Michael's surprise when he landed in Auckland, not Oakland. He admitted the blunder and Air New Zealand officials gave Michael a return ticket to LA, and he eventually arrived at his intended destination. This story is kindly shared by colleague Chris Huet and is perfect for communications training. Key learnings for communications training: - Clarity is king: Be crystal clear in communication to avoid unexpected detours. - Listen actively: Pay attention to the details, especially in travel plans or instructions. - Speak up: If something seems off, don't hesitate to ask for clarification. What's your favourite training story? Share it below and let's inspire each other! #learningdesign #trainingcourses #corporatetraining #skillsdevelopment #learninganddevelopment

#bahnlife ep. 22 International transit. I sometimes work on international trains, mainly to Switzerland/Basel. And it is still a pain, to cross borders with the trains. The connections are few and far between, which means that connecting trains are a problem. Some Train companies don't accept tickets from other companies (you missed your ice to Bruxelles ? you can't take the Thalys just like that, you need a HOTNAT [Hop On The Next Available Train] certificate...) then some countries like France or Italy have mandatory reservations and their trains are normally at over 80% capacity (so you can imagine what peak time looks like). it's getting better (after it got way worse in the last 20 years with the disappearance of most of the InterCities, EuroCities, and nighttrains). Anyway, dear EU, there is work to do here to reduce flying within Europe

The ranking of shame of those who travel the most by private jet in Spain and in the world It is a shame for several reasons. In the case of politicians, they are the ones who have the responsibility of taking actions to clean the air of polluting gases, and yet they are the ones who pollute the most through their private jet trips. In the case of the elites, there is everything, there are those who use the plane for flights even of 5 minutes, because they only get into their Lincoln or Rolls Royce to cross the street. The truth is that legislation should be legislated to prevent abuse, but the opposite is done. In Europe there is strong political opposition to the regulation of private flights, why is that?

I‚Äôve been part of the Canadian aviation community for more than a decade, and it astounds me how many of my respected industry colleagues are eager to criticize Flair Airlines. At times, it feels like some even resent their very existence and their ‚Äúunsustainable‚Äù business model. Yet they gush over WestJet‚Äôs brilliant and very successful introduction of a new no frills fare option like UltraBasic. Well, colleagues, it‚Äôs time to move on. Flair has been around for quite a while now, and though I may eat my words one day (I hope not), it seems the ULC operator is here to stay, even in this most difficult air travel environment that is Canada. Instead of constantly praising WestJet perhaps these industry pundits could fairly scrutinize their on-time performance or completion rate as well? Disclaimer: Yes, I am a bit grumpy after arriving at Pearson after a long overseas flight to be greeted with a 2.5-hour delay for my connection to Edmonton. And while in this instance I‚Äôd prefer to be travelling Flair‚Äôs on-time 22:15 flight as opposed to the delayed WS one, nonetheless, I am truly grateful for the colossal economic impact both of these airlines continue to have in Alberta and the country. #Aviation #AviationIndustry #AlbertaAviation #AAC #AlbertaAviationCouncil #CanadianAviation
